abstract.p: Ajoy Vachher letter on Tony Hackett's May 14 profile of track star Marion Jones questions when people will stop ascribing success of African-American athletes to genetic makeup rather than talent, hard work and discipline

block.p: Hackett explains Marion Jones's success (May 14) in terms of her ''genetic makeup'' and of being ''born strong, with fast-twitch muscles.'' Yet Hackett goes on to describe the 100-meter sprint, her ''signature event,'' as ''the most technical and intellectual of all track events.'' He also describes her mental strength, rigorous self-appraisal, willingness to change, incredible discipline, pragmatism and hard work.

Yet Hackett goes on to describe the 100-meter sprint, her ''signature event,'' as ''the most technical and intellectual of all track events.'' He also describes her mental strength, rigorous self-appraisal, willingness to change, incredible discipline, pragmatism and hard work.

It makes me wonder, therefore, when people will stop ascribing the success of African-American athletes to genetic good fortune and instead ascribe it to the talent, hard work and discipline all highly successful athletes must possess to succeed.
